(Same as JS 271 2, REL 270 10)
The Holocaust: History & Memory
This is an introductory course on the Holocaust: its origins, implementation, and aftermath. Situating the genocide of European Jews in a broader history and as a global event, the course concentrates on the 20th century and has three geographical focuses: Germany as a birthplace of Nazi ideology, Eastern Europe as the epicenter of genocide, and the United States as an example of world reaction. 
We will investigate the experience of understudied and underrepresented groups such as women, queer people, youth, workers, and people of color. Through the evolution of Nazi policy from discrimination and exclusion to mass killing, we will examine how ideology both motivates and legitimizes racialized violence. Looking at a wide range of groups and individuals, we will examine the choices they confronted, their motivations, the pressures they faced, and the actions they took. While considering the conditions of perpetrators, victims, and bystanders, we will also address instances in which those roles blurred and overlapped. 
Challenging popular myths and oversimplified explanations, we will view the Holocaust as a historical event 'neither inevitable nor inexplicable' and consider its implications for the present. To do so, we will utilize primary sources such as survivors' testimonies, historical artifacts (art, everyday objects, etc.), diaries and letters, and visual material.
